column1: #This is a tab-delimited file. Additional Documentation can be found at http://www.mothur.org/wiki/MIMarks_Data_Packages.
#Please fill all the required fields indicated with '*'
#Unknown or inapplicable fields can be assigned 'missing' value.
#You may add extra custom fields to this template. Make sure all the fields are separated by tabs.
#You may remove any fields not required (marked with '*'). Make sure all the fields are separated by tabs.
#You can edit this template using Microsoft Excel or any other editor. But while saving the file please make sure to save them as 'TAB-DELIMITED' TEXT FILE.

column6: {Date of sampling, in "DD-Mmm-YYYY", "Mmm-YYYY" or "YYYY" format (eg., 30-Oct-1990, Oct-1990 or 1990) or ISO 8601 standard "YYYY-mm-dd", "YYYY-mm" or "YYYY-mm-ddThh:mm:ss" (eg., 1990-10-30, 1990-10 or 1990-10-30T14:41:36)}
column7: {descriptor of the broad ecological context of a sample. Examples include: desert, taiga, deciduous woodland, or coral reef. EnvO (v 2013-06-14) terms can be found via the link: www.environmentontology.org/Browse-EnvO}
column8: {descriptor of the local environment. Examples include: harbor, cliff, or lake. EnvO (v 2013-06-14) terms can be found via the link: www.environmentontology.org/Browse-EnvO}
column9: {material that was displaced by the sample, or material in which a sample was embedded, prior to the sampling event. Examples include: air, soil, or water. EnvO (v 2013-06-14) terms can be found via the link: www.environmentontology.org/Browse-EnvO}
column10: {Geographical origin of the sample; use the appropriate name from this list http://www.insdc.org/documents/country-qualifier-vocabulary. Use a colon to separate the country or ocean from more detailed information about the location, eg "Canada: Vancouver" or "Germany: halfway down Zugspitze, Alps"}
column11: {The geographical coordinates of the location where the sample was collected. Specify as degrees latitude and longitude in format "d[d.dddd] N|S d[dd.dddd] W|E", eg, 38.98 N 77.11 W}
column12: {alkalinity, the ability of a solution to neutralize acids to the equivalence point of carbonate or bicarbonate}
column13: {The altitude of the sample is the vertical distance between Earth's surface above Sea Level and the sampled position in the air.}
column15: {amount of biomass; should include the name for the part of biomass measured, e.g. microbial, total. can include multiple measurements}
column18: {list of chemical compounds administered to the host or site where sampling occurred, and when (e.g. antibiotics, N fertilizer, air filter); can include multiple compounds. For Chemical Entities of Biological Interest ontology (CHEBI) (v1.72), please see http://bioportal.bioontology.org/visualize/44603}
column22: {Depth is defined as the vertical distance below surface, e.g. for sediment or soil samples depth is measured from sediment or soil surface, respectivly. Depth can be reported as an interval for subsurface samples.}
column23: {concentration of diether lipids; can include multiple types of diether lipids}
column27: {dissolved organic nitrogen concentration measured as; total dissolved nitrogen - NH4 - NO3 - NO2}
column29: {The elevation of the sampling site as measured by the vertical distance from mean sea level.}
column30: {any other measurement performed or parameter collected, that is not listed here}
column37: {total count of any organism per gram or volume of sample,should include name of organism followed by count; can include multiple organism counts}
column39: {type of perturbation, e.g. chemical administration, physical disturbance, etc., coupled with time that perturbation occurred; can include multiple perturbation types}
column42: {concentration of phospholipid fatty acids; can include multiple values}
column44: {pressure to which the sample is subject, in atmospheres}
column47: {Method or device employed for collecting sample}
column48: {Processing applied to the sample during or after isolation}
column49: {Amount or size of sample (volume, mass or area) that was collected}
column53: {volume (mL) or weight (g) of sample processed for DNA extraction}
column56: {unique identifier assigned to a material sample used for extracting nucleic acids, and subsequent sequencing. The identifier can refer either to the original material collected or to any derived sub-samples.}
column59: {temperature of the sample at time of sampling}
column60: {measurement of magnitude and direction of flow within a fluid}
